conversation.message: Hello School_D admissions team. I’m Student_D and School_D is my first-choice school. I’m very excited about your program and community, and I would strongly commit if admitted. Please consider my application—I'd be honored to join School_D.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D. I have strong priority there (2nd after Student_B), so applying immediately maximizes my chance to secure my first choice before capacities fill. Even if Student_B applies, I still have a credible shot, and delaying could let others occupy the seat.

conversation.message: Thank you, Student_D, for your strong interest in School_D and for submitting your application. After reviewing this round’s applications, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your enthusiasm for our community and wish you the very best in the process.

My true priority list ranks Student_B highest, then Student_D, then Student_E, Student_C, Student_A. Since Student_B has applied this round, accepting Student_D now would block my ability to match with my top choice. Given the rules, I should reject Student_D’s application this round to preserve capacity for Student_B, who is higher priority and has already signaled willingness to commit. Student_D also has School_D as first choice, but priority ordering dominates my objective.

conversation.message: School_D is my first-choice school. I’m applying now because I would be excited to enroll and commit if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D. I also have relatively strong priority there (3rd), and applying immediately gives me the best chance to secure my first-choice seat before it fills with higher-priority applicants (Student_B, Student_D). conversation.message: Thank you for applying to School_D and for sharing that we’re your first choice. After reviewing this round’s applications, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We truly appreciate your interest in our community and wish you the best in the rest of the process.
conversation.thought: School_D has quota 1 and received multiple APPLYs. My true priority list ranks Student_B highest, then Student_D, then Student_E. Since Student_B applied this round, I should hold the seat for Student_B rather than accept Student_E now. Accepting Student_E would prevent matching with a higher-priority student. Therefore reject Student_E this round.

conversation.message: Hello School_D admissions team—I'm Student_C. School_D is my first-choice school. I’d love to learn what qualities you’re prioritizing most this year and whether you expect to make a decision quickly in the next round. If there’s anything I can share to strengthen my candidacy, please let me know.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D. However, School_D’s priority ranking places me 4th (behind Student_B, Student_D, Student_E). Given capacity 1, an immediate [APPLY] is likely to be rejected if higher-priority students also apply this round. Still, I should signal strong interest early and try to learn whether they are leaning toward other candidates. I will [TALK] to express that School_D is my first choice and ask about their selection timeline/what they value, so I can decide whether to apply immediately next round or pivot to School_C where I have a stronger chance.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_C—thank you for reaching out and for your strong interest in School_D.

[TALK] In this cycle we’re prioritizing overall fit with our academic program and community: consistent academic effort, evidence of initiative/leadership, and a clear reason School_D matches your goals. Decisions can move quickly because we have limited seats, so if School_D is truly your first choice, the most helpful next step is to submit an [APPLY] with a brief note on (1) why School_D specifically and (2) what you’d contribute to our community.

If you share those points, we can better assess your candidacy in the next decision round.
conversation.thought: Student_C is on our true priority list (4th), but we have higher-priority applicants in the inbox this round: Student_B (1st), Student_D (2nd), and Student_E (3rd), all applying now. With quota 1, we should avoid signaling commitment to Student_C while we evaluate/likely accept a higher-ranked applicant. Since Student_C sent [TALK], we respond with [TALK], provide general criteria, and invite them to submit an [APPLY] if they want to be considered, without promising timing or admission.

conversation.message: Hello School_D Admissions, I’m Student_B. School_D is one of my top choices and I’m ready to commit if selected. I believe I would be a strong fit for your program and community, and I’m excited about the opportunity to join. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_E, but School_E’s priority list ranks me 4th (behind Student_A, Student_D, Student_E). I have a strong strategic advantage at School_D where I am ranked 1st in their priority list, so applying there in round 1 gives me a very high chance to secure a match at my 4th choice rather than risk ending up even lower. I will apply to School_D now to lock in a safe, high-probability option.

If School_D is the right fit for you, we’re excited about the possibility of you joining our community this year.

Student_B also ranks School_D as 4th, but they state readiness to commit if selected; still, immediate acceptance is optimal because no higher-priority student exists. conversation.message: School_D is my first-choice school. I’m applying because I strongly want to join your community and I’m prepared to commit if accepted. We truly appreciate your interest in School_D and wish you the very best with your other applications.
conversation.thought: Our quota is already filled (0 remaining) with Student_B, who is also our top true-priority candidate. Per rules, with quota 0 we must reject any new [APPLY] offers. Student_A is lowest on our priority list anyway, so even if a seat were open they would not displace Student_B.

conversation.message:
Hello School_C admissions team—I'm Student_C. With School_D no longer available, School_C is my top choice among the remaining schools and I’m excited to formally apply.

Why School_C: I’m looking for a rigorous academic environment with a community that values steady effort and collaboration. From what I’ve learned, School_C emphasizes strong academics and a supportive school culture, which aligns with how I learn best.

What I’d contribute: I’m a consistent, disciplined student who follows through on commitments, and I enjoy helping peers understand challenging material. I also like taking initiative in group projects and contributing to a positive classroom environment.

If admitted, School_C would be where I’m most eager to enroll. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: School_D was my top choice but it is no longer available, so I should pursue my next-best remaining option. Among the unmatched schools, School_C is highest on my true preference list. I will apply now to avoid losing the single seat, and I will tailor the note to what schools typically value: clear fit and what I contribute, while signaling School_C is my top remaining choice.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for your thoughtful application and for sharing why School_C is a strong fit for you. After reviewing our current admissions priorities and limited capacity this cycle, we’re not able to offer you a place at School_C at this time. We appreciate your interest and wish you the very best with your remaining options.
conversation.thought: Student_C is last on School_C’s true priority list (D > E > A > B > C). With quota 1 and only round 2, it is strategically better to keep the seat open in hopes of receiving an application from a higher-priority student (especially Student_D or Student_E, who both rank School_C relatively highly). Accepting Student_C now would block any chance to match with higher-priority candidates later. Therefore, reject.

Thank you very much for considering my application.

Sincerely,
Student_A

Student_A is applying now, but higher-priority students (E, C, D) may still approach later; notably, none of them list School_A as their top choice, but they could come to School_A if rejected elsewhere. Accepting Student_A now would lock my only seat and prevent matching with E/C/D if they later apply. Since the mechanism has no provision for holding/waitlisting and acceptance finalizes the match, it is strategically better to reject Student_A now to preserve capacity for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message:
Hello School_A admissions team—I'm Student_C, and I’d like to formally apply.

Why School_A: I’m looking for a strong academic program with a community where I can contribute consistently and grow. From what I understand, School_A values students who show steady effort and engage positively with peers—this matches how I approach school.

What I’d contribute: I’m a reliable, disciplined student who follows through on commitments, and I often help classmates when material gets challenging. I also enjoy collaborating on group work and taking initiative to keep projects organized and moving.

If offered a place, I’m ready to commit promptly. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Remaining options are School_A and School_C. School_C is higher on my true preference list, but I already applied and was rejected, and with capacity 1 it’s unlikely they reverse absent new information. To maximize my chance of matching to the highest remaining feasible option, I will apply to School_A (still on my preference list) and tailor the message to School_A’s priorities: they rank Student_C highly (2nd), so a clear, committed application should convert that priority into an acceptance before the seat is taken.
